name: Satellite pendant
description:
Shibuichi set with Australian sapphires.

These lovely sapphires look black but in the brightest light when their blue can be glimpsed. 

On an oxidised sterling silver chain with gold fob.

Perhaps it was Catriona McKenzie’s film Satellite Boy that inspired these this year, the film  moved my son and me and  its  sound track has been on high rotation. Or perhaps it has been our year of clear evening skies.

name: Shirakawa silver brooch
description:
Brooches from my Shide series. 

Approx 65mm x 52mm.

Folded bits of silver and gold that follow the pattern of shide seen at temples in Japan. Shide are sheets of white paper cut, folded and used in Shinto rituals. They are often hung from plaited rice rope (shimenawa 注連縄) to signify the presence of spirits or ward off demons.

These brooches also look fabulous worn as a pendant long or short on a chain or silk rope. Contact me if you would like me to arrange something suitable.

options.name: 18ct yellow gold bonded to Sterling silver

name: Green Gold Ring
description:
Baguette cut Gympie chrysoprase in 18ct gold.

This ring has a wonderful weight but is entirely comfortable to wear.

Size K.

Love.

As a bit of fun this fabulous creature makes an featured appearance in this little film. 
https://vimeo.com/79453150
If you blink you might miss it.

name: Marcasite swallows
description: Historically a token representing safe travels these vintage swallows have been framed in a window of shakudo and 14ct yellow gold on an oxidised silver chain.

name: Ocean's Blue opal earrings
description:
Stunning, glittery blue green boulder opal and diamonds in 18ct gold and shakudo.

Ocean's blue, opal's hue...

Lightning Ridge black opal and Mt Surprise topaz cut by Doug Menadue, set in 18ct gold and shibuichi.

This winter's walks found me consumed by our pacific’s various and changing hues. The white and greys as the subdued winter sun tickled the cresting waves. The stoney grey of the rocky foreshore, the well washed beige of the sand. The myriad blue grey of the cool water.

There was a particular day on which I noticed the season’s change. The light warmed. Sand newly golden, sky blue, the ocean clear turquoise…teal…aqua.

And so I was drawn to a collection of pieces in Australian blue gemstones. Opal the most appropriate place to start.

name: Silver ginko leaf brooch
description:
Sterling silver ginko leaves.

Chromium pin

Please note: There are muliple in the picture. You only get one for the price below :)

Limited edition, each a different leaf.

name: Alluvial earrings
description:
Alluvial gold and shakudo with 18ct yellow gold.

I was first inspired to make these when lovely man dropped in to have the gold he had found melted into bars. What fun!

I grew attached to a few tiny nuggets and he kindly sold them to me. I have combined them each with shakudo—a japanese alloy (6% gold, 94% copper)—and am totally in love with these tiny black and gold bits.

name: Orogen pendant
description:
Inspired by the folded red quartzite rock faces of the MacDonnell Ranges in Central Australia.

350-300 million years ago a mountain building event created the MacDonnell Ranges. Since that time, folding, faulting and erosion have shaped the range and created numerous gaps and gorges that we see today. The complexity of the exposed faults is astonishing and totally captured my attention. It creates the illusion of individual bricks. I could sit and follow the lines with my eyes for hours.

The orogen collection began my explorations in Japanese irogane. This technique alloys copper with different metals.  The objects are boiled in a niage patina bath to produce a wonderful palette of browns and greys.

The materials used are:
Sterling silver (92.5% silver, 7.5% copper) – white
Shibuichi (25% silver, 75% copper) – grey
Shakudo (6% gold, 94% copper) – black
Copper – caramel

Pendant on a 70cm sterling silver chain with a yellow gold fob.

name: Australian ruby and shakudo ring
description:
Flawless fossicked ruby found at Rubyvale Queensland. Very rare! Perfectly cut by champion gem cutter John Alan.

Set in 22ct gold and shakudo.

name: Ocean's blue black opal earrings
description:
Ocean's blue, opal's hue.

Lightning Ridge black opal and Mt Surprise topaz cut by Doug Menadue, set in 18ct gold and shibuichi.

This winter's walks found me consumed by our pacific’s various and changing hues. The white and greys as the subdued winter sun tickled the cresting waves. The stoney grey of the rocky foreshore, the well washed beige of the sand. The myriad blue grey of the cool water.

There was a particular day on which I noticed the season’s change. The light warmed. Sand newly golden, sky blue, the ocean clear turquoise…teal…aqua.

And so I was drawn to a collection of pieces in Australian blue gemstones. Opal the most appropriate place to start.

name: Alluvial pendant (small)
description:
Western Australian alluvial gold nugget in 6% Shakudo, treated with Niage. 

On oxidized sterling silver chain with gold fob.

These began when a lovely man dropped in to have the gold he had found melted into bars. What fun!

I grew attached to a few tiny nuggets and he kindly sold them to me. I have combined them each with shakudo—a japanese alloy (6% gold, 94% copper)—and am totally in love with these tiny black and gold bits.

name: Morton bay fig brooch
description:
Sterling silver brooch with chromium pin.

Brushed finish.

Approx 65mm x 25mm

Limited edition. Each brooch is cut from an individual leaf.

name: Ocean's Blue opal pendant
description:
Ocean's blue, opal's hue.

Australian boulder opal, black sapphire and diamond with moonstone and turquoise, set in a pendant of white gold and shibuichi, on a white gold fob chain.

This winter's walks found me consumed by our pacific’s various and changing hues. The white and greys as the subdued winter sun tickled the cresting waves. The stoney grey of the rocky foreshore, the well washed beige of the sand. The myriad blue grey of the cool water.

There was a particular day on which I noticed the season’s change. The light warmed. Sand newly golden, sky blue, the ocean clear turquoise…teal…aqua.

And so I was drawn to a collection of pieces in Australian blue gemstones. Opal the most appropriate place to start.

name: Green gold necklace
description:
Necklace of chrysoprase, saltwater pearls, 24ct gold, shakudo and 18ct gold.

Chrysoprase is a gemstone variety of chalcedony that contains small quantities of nickel making it green. The word chrysoprase comes from the Greek χρυσός (chrysos) meaning ‘gold’ and πράσινο (prásino) meaning ‘green’. Queensland has one of the worlds largest supplies. From here it is mostly exported to Asia where it is treated and often marketed misleadingly as Jade.

These chrysoprase beads are from Marlborough and are a rarity as making beads out of local materials is not cost effective for the Australian market. The miners who had these produced have told me they will not be doing it again.

name: Green gold earrings
description:
Earrings of chrysoprase, 18ct yellow gold and shakudo.

Chrysoprase is a gemstone variety of chalcedony that contains small quantities of nickel making it green. The word chrysoprase comes from the Greek χρυσός (chrysos) meaning ‘gold’ and πράσινο (prásino) meaning ‘green’. Queensland has one of the worlds largest supplies. From here it is mostly exported to Asia where it is treated and often marketed misleadingly as Jade.

These chrysoprase beads are from Marlborough and are a rarity as making beads out of local materials is not cost effective for the Australian market. The miners who had these produced have told me they will not be doing it again.

name: Alluvial dragon pendant
description:
A little alluvial gold dragon circled in shakudo and 18ct yellow gold, on an oxidized sterling silver chain with yellow gold fob.

I was inspired to start this series these when lovely man dropped in to have the gold he had found melted into bars. What fun!

I grew attached to a few tiny nuggets and he kindly sold them to me. I have combined them each with shakudo—a japanese alloy (6% gold, 94% copper)—and am totally in love with these tiny black and gold bits.

name: Window pendant
description:
This pendant was inspired by timber windows I saw in Japan.

Sterling silver, on a sterling silver snake chain with 14ct yellow gold fob.

Approx 60mm x 60mm

Chain approx 75cm.

Folded bits of silver and gold that follow the pattern of shide seen at temples in Japan. Shide are sheets of white paper cut, folded and used in Shinto rituals. They are often hung from plaited rice rope (shimenawa 注連縄) to signify the presence of spirits or ward off demons.

These brooches also look fabulous worn as a pendant long or short on a chain or silk rope. Contact me if you would like me to arrange something suitable.

options.name: 18ct yellow gold bonded to sterling silver

name: Poffertjes square brooch
description:
These treasures bring to mind all the tasty little treats cooked in the larger cast iron version. Poffertjes, peach blossoms, gem scones.

As my sisters will attest, the gem iron treats from our childhood were savoury. Tiny yorkshire puddings and creamed corn toast canapé are two I recall.

My grandmother was known for her sweeter treats baked in the same tins—wonderful peach blossoms.

name: Orogen brooch
description:
Inspired by the folded red quartzite rock faces of the MacDonnell Ranges in Central Australia.

350-300 million years ago a mountain building event created the MacDonnell Ranges. Since that time, folding, faulting and erosion have shaped the range and created numerous gaps and gorges that we see today. The complexity of the exposed faults is astonishing and totally captured my attention. It creates the illusion of individual bricks. I could sit and follow the lines with my eyes for hours.

The orogen collection began my explorations in Japanese irogane. This technique alloys copper with different metals. The objects are boiled in a niage patina bath to produce a wonderful palette of browns and greys.

The materials used are:
Sterling silver (92.5% silver, 7.5% copper) – white
Shibuichi (25% silver, 75% copper) – grey
Shakudo (6% gold, 94% copper) – black

name: Satellite pendant shakudo
description:
Diamonds set in shakudo on an oxidised silver chain with gold fob.

Perhaps it was Catriona McKenzie’s film Satellite Boy that inspired these this year, the film really moved my son and me, its fabulous sound track has been on high rotation. Perhaps it has been our year of clear evening skies. Or maybe it is simply being part of the flow of diamonds in and out of the workshop at Sunstate.

I have grown quite fond of warm diamonds. Not the most highly prized but for me the most friendly each with showing subtly different personality within their sparkling brilliance.

The perfect complement to the depth and complexity of shakudo.

name: Alluvial circle earrings
description:
I was first inspired to make these when lovely man dropped in to have the gold he had found melted into bars. What fun!

I grew attached to a few tiny nuggets and he kindly sold them to me. I have combined them each with shakudo—a japanese alloy (6% gold, 94% copper)—and am totally in love with these tiny black and gold bits.

Alluvial gold and shakudo on 9ct yellow gold hooks.

Sterling silver belt. Buckle and clasp star set with Australian black sapphires and warm diamonds.

Lovely worn on waist or hips.

Chain mail approx 30mm wide.
Buckle 60mmx75mm approx.

500gms

name: Poffetjes brooch
description:
These treasures bring to mind all the tasty little treats cooked in the larger cast iron version. Poffertjes, peach blossoms, gem scones.

As my sisters will attest, the gem iron treats from our childhood were savoury. Tiny yorkshire puddings and creamed corn toast canapé are two I recall.

My grandmother was known for her sweeter treats baked in the same tins—wonderful peach blossoms.

name: Shibuichi ginko leaf
description:
Chromium pin

We have such lovely flora in South East Queensland. Picking up leaves at the beach is a favourite pastime. Leaves make particularly good sandcastle adornments.

One evening while stopping for a quick swim I was greeted by a wonderful sandcastle. The beach was empty. The small formation was a simple mound covered in round brown leaves. It caught the setting sunlight and glowed gold. Glorious.

name: Co'chlear pendant - grey on grey
description:
Co’chlear pendant on hand made chain. Shibuichi treated with niage.

Pendant approx: 40mm x 40mm

Sterling silver chain 17mm links, approx 45cm length

name: Beach Vine Necklace
description:
Single strand silver necklace. The small hook can be fastened to wear the piece whatever length suits your mood.

Sterling silver. 

Approx 20gms, 90cm.

Limited edition. As you can see from the images each of these necklaces is slightly different. No one else will ever have one the same as yours.

PLEASE NOTE: There are two shown in some of these pictures. You only get one for the price below ;)

name: Yoshida pendant
description:
Folded from 0.5mm precious metal. This pendant comes on a silver chain with 14ct yellow gold fob.

Pendant size approx 45mm x 15mm.

Chain length 48 mm approx.

Limited edition

These folded bits of silver and gold follow the pattern of shide seen at temples in Japan. Shide are sheets of white paper cut, folded and used in Shinto rituals. They are often hung from plaited rice rope (shimenawa 注連縄) to signify the presence of spirits or ward off demons.
